item.title: ONS launches shopping prices comparison tool
item.description: ONS launches shopping prices comparison tool 03 May 2023 The Office for National Statistics (ONS) has released a new tool allowing you to compare the average prices of over 450 items in the consumer prices inflation basket. In the past year, 95% of these items have increased in price , with cucumbers (up 52%), olive oil (up 49%) and hard cheese (up 44%) seeing the largest increases. The tool contains items ranging from bananas to nursery fees and aims to help improve the accessibility of existing ONS data by easily allowing users to track average price trends. As well as showing average price changes on an item-by-item basis, the tool also lets you create your own bespoke basket of items and calculate the total average price change across these items. For example, a roast dinner for four people, including a whole chicken weighing (1.5kg), white potatoes (1kg), carrots (1 kg), broccoli (350g) and butter (100g), could cost ¬£8.68 on average in March 2023, based on a 2023 sample. This is ¬£1.68 more than in March 2022, with broccoli recording the highest increase at 34%. The tool will be updated every month to reflect the latest inflation data and will be refreshed each March to accommodate the latest changes to the items in the inflation basket . ü†ï Back to the top

item.title: Almost a third of businesses are experiencing worker shortages
item.description: Almost a third of businesses are experiencing worker shortages 05 May 2023 Almost a third (31%) of businesses with 10 or more employees are experiencing worker shortages, up 2 percentage points from late March 2023. The final results from Wave 81 of the Business Insights and Conditions Survey (BICS) asked businesses with 10 or more employees whether they were experiencing worker shortages. More than half (53%) of those affected indicated that their employees were working increased hours consequently. According to data from Adzuna, the total number of online job adverts grew by 1% on 28 April 2023 compared with the previous week. Online job adverts have broadly trended downwards over the last 12 months and is now 17% lower than the equivalent period of 2022. In the latest week, Revolut debit card spending increased by 16 percentage points, with increases in every sector. The largest sector increase was retail which increased by 26 percentage points. Elsewhere, overall retail footfall increased to 105% of the level of the previous week. Read our Economic activity and social change in the UK, real-time indicators bulletin ü†ï Back to the top Cost of living increased for 7 in 10 UK adults 05 May 2023 Around 7 in 10 (70%) adults reported that their cost of living has increased compared with a month ago, when asked between April 19 and May 1. This is according to our latest Public Opinions and Social Trends release. The most common reasons for the rising cost of living reported by adults were the increase in food shopping prices (97%), an increase in gas or electricity bills (73%) and an increase in the price of fuel (40%). More than half of adults (51%) said that in the past two weeks they were worried about the cost of food. More than 4 in 10 (48%) said that they were worried about the cost of energy, and around a third (33%) were concerned about their general health. In the same period, nearly two-thirds of adults (63%) said that they were spending less on non-essentials, and 4 in 10 (40%) said that they were spending more than usual to get what they normally buy when food shopping. item.title: UK GDP estimated to have increased 0.1% in the first quarter of 2023
item.description: UK GDP estimated to have increased 0.1% in the first quarter of 2023 12 May 2023 The first quarterly estimate of real gross domestic product (GDP) shows that the UK economy grew by 0.1% in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2023. Real GDP is estimated to have increased by 0.1% in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2023 UK, Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2022 to Quarter 1 2023 Source: GDP first quarterly estimate from the Office for National Statistics Notes: Q1 refers to Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar), Q2 refers to Quarter 2 (Apr to June), Q3 refers to Quarter 3 (July to Sept) and Q4 refers to Quarter 4 (Oct to Dec). No periods are open to revision in this publication. Download this chart Real GDP is estimated to have increased by 0.1% in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2023 Image .csv .xls The services sector grew by 0.1% in Quarter 1 2023 with the largest positive contributor being information and communication which grew by 1.2%, with increases in computer programming, consultancy and related activities; and telecommunications. Production output increased by 0.1% in Quarter 1 2023 following no growth in the previous quarter and five consecutive falls before that. Elsewhere, construction output increased for the sixth consecutive quarter. The implied price of GDP was 6.3% higher in Quarter 1 2023 than the same quarter a year ago. Growth has been driven by strong rises in household spending due to recent inflationary pressures, though these price increases are slowing. Read our latest bulletin on UK quarterly GDP. ü†ï Back to the top UK trade fell in March 2023 12 May 2023 In March 2023, the total value of UK goods imports decreased by ¬£1.4 billion (2.8%), and goods exports fell by ¬£0.7 billion (2.3%) compared with February 2023. The monthly falls in both imported and exported goods, were primarily because of decreases in trade with non-EU countries, while trade with the EU remained stable. Imports of goods from non-EU countries continued to decrease in March 2023, while imports from the EU remained stable EU and non-EU goods imports and exports, excluding precious metals, current prices, seasonally adjusted, January 2020 to March 2023 Embed code Embed this interactive Copy Download the data .xlsx Notes: HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) data collection changes following EU exit have affected statistics on UK trade in goods with the EU. Our Impact of trade in goods data collection changes on UK trade statistics articles provide more detail. The unchanged level of imports from the EU in March 2023 was because of a rise in imports of machinery and transport equipment being offset by a fall in fuel imports. All other commodities remained stable in March. The quarterly trade in goods deficit narrowed by ¬£8.9 billion to ¬£55.0 billion in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2023, while the trade in services surplus widened by ¬£1.3 billion to ¬£39.8 billion. These changes to the quarterly trade balances were primarily because of falls of ¬£3.8 billion in machinery and transport equipment imports, ¬£3.3 billion in fuel imports and ¬£2.0 billion in imports of other business services. The total trade in goods and services deficit narrowed by ¬£10.2 billion to ¬£15.1 billion in Quarter 1 2023, whereas exports fell by a lesser ¬£5.2 billion. Read our latest UK trade: March 2023 bulletin ü†ï Back to the top In March 2023 construction output increased by 0.2% 12 May 2023 In March 2023 construction output in Great Britain is estimated to have increased by 0.2% compared to February 2023, and by 4.1% compared to March 2022. March 2023 had the highest construction output (¬£15,616 million) since records began. The increase in monthly construction output was caused by a 0.7% increase in new work, while repair and maintenance decreased by 0.6%. The increase in construction output compared to March 2022 was caused by a 6.1% increase in repair and maintenance, and a 2.8% increase in new work. At the sector level, the main reasons for the monthly increase were increases in ‚Äúinfrastructure new work‚Äù and ‚Äúpublic other new work‚Äù sectors; which increased by 2.2% (¬£51 million) and 6.5% (¬£48 million), respectively. Construction output increased 0.7% in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2023 compared with Quarter 4 (Oct to Dec) 2022. This increase came solely from a rise in repair and maintenance (4.9%), as new work saw a decrease of 1.9%. Total construction new orders decreased by 12.4% (A decrease of ¬£1,571 million) in Quarter 1 2023 compared with Quarter 4 2022; this quarterly fall came mainly from ‚Äúprivate commercial‚Äù and ‚Äúprivate housing new orders‚Äù, which fell 22.3% (¬£773 million) and 18.4% (¬£607 million), respectively. The annual rate of construction output price growth was 8.5% in the 12 months to March 2023; this has slowed slightly from the record annual price growths in both May 2022 and June 2022 (10.4%).
